description: OAPEC embargo on US and allies during Yom Kippur War; oil prices quadrupled.
source: U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA) — Historical/market chronology of the 1973–74 oil embargo (EIA energy history materials); BP Statistical Review — historical oil price/market context

description: Iranian Revolution disrupted production causing global supply shortages and price spikes.
source: EIA — country/market history on Iran and global supply disruptions (EIA energy history/country analysis); IEA — Oil Market Reports (historical coverage) on 1979–80 supply disruption

description: Iraq invaded Kuwait leading to sharp oil price increases and supply risks.
source: EIA — 'Iraq invades Kuwait' and 1990–91 Gulf War oil market impacts (EIA chronology/analysis); IEA — contemporaneous Oil Market Report summaries on 1990 supply loss

description: Regional recession reduced oil demand causing prices to fall sharply.
source: IMF — World Economic Outlook (1997–1999) on Asia crisis and global demand; World Bank — East Asia crisis reports and macro impacts relevant to energy demand

description: Coordinated output cuts helped recover oil prices after late 1990s slump.
source: OPEC — Press releases / Monthly Oil Market Report (MOMR) (1999) documenting quota decisions; EIA — analysis of 1999 OPEC cuts and price recovery

description: Financial crisis reduced demand; oil dropped from record highs to below $40.
source: IMF — Global Financial Stability Report / WEO (2008–2009) on demand shock; EIA — 2008 oil price collapse analysis; IEA — Oil Market Report (2008–2009) demand revisions

event_name: Arab Spring / Libya Civil War Supply Loss
description: Libyan exports halted, tightening supply and raising Brent prices.
source: IEA — Oil Market Report (2011) detailing Libyan outage volumes; EIA — Libya supply disruption analysis (2011) and Brent market impact summaries

description: Rapid US shale production growth caused oversupply and prolonged price decline.
source: EIA — U.S. tight oil / crude production statistics and 2014–2016 market analysis; IEA — Oil Market Report (2014–2016) on non-OPEC supply growth

description: OPEC and Russia agreed to coordinated production cuts to rebalance market.
source: OPEC — official communications on 30 Nov 2016 agreement and subsequent conformity reports; IEA — Oil Market Report (2016–2018) on OPEC+ cuts and balances

description: Lockdowns slashed travel and fuel demand; prices plunged and WTI briefly turned negative.
source: IEA — Oil Market Report (2020) and Global Energy Review (2020) on demand collapse; EIA — 2020 petroleum market and price impact analysis

description: Breakdown of talks led to production surge and severe price crash.
source: OPEC — meeting outcomes/communications (March–April 2020); IEA — Oil Market Report (Mar–Apr 2020) describing supply surge and price impacts; EIA — contemporaneous market commentary

description: Record coordinated cuts to stabilize collapsing prices.
source: OPEC — official statement on 12 April 2020 Declaration of Cooperation adjustments; IEA — Oil Market Report (2020–2021) tracking cuts and market rebalancing

description: Sanctions and supply disruptions raised volatility and energy security concerns.
source: IEA — Russia’s invasion of Ukraine: energy security analysis and monthly market updates; EIA — analysis of sanctions, trade flows, and global price impacts (2022–2023)

description: Additional voluntary cuts aimed at supporting prices amid weak demand outlook.
source: OPEC — press releases on voluntary adjustments (April 2023 onward) and MOMR references; IEA — Oil Market Report updates describing OPEC+ supply policy changes (2023–2024)

description: Attacks on shipping routes increased freight costs and oil supply risk premiums.
source: UNCTAD — Red Sea/Suez trade disruption updates (2023–2024); International Maritime Organization (IMO) security updates; market monitoring from IEA/EIA on freight and supply risk premia
